chapter.title: Elements of being proactive
chapter.content:
Elements of being proactive

Planning is important, but planning won’t be helpful unless a person can take action. The elements of being proactive include:

  • taking appropriate risks;
  • gaining support and resources;
  • communicating and negotiating;
  • coping with criticism; and
  • initiating action when needed - using the appropriate skills.

chapter.title: Questions related to being proactive
chapter.content:
Questions related to being proactive

A self-determined person can answer these questions:

  • What are my communication strengths and weaknesses?
  • How well am I able to accept another person’s point of view?
  • What are my strengths in giving and accepting feedback?
  • What do I do when I meet a roadblock to reaching a goal?

Note that in this list, and in the elements listed previously, communicating with others can be an important part of being proactive. Communication skills are particularly important for individuals with LD, as many have language-based deficits that can mean challenges in one or more forms of communication.

Because individuals with LD have often experienced a lot of school failure, the considerations in the other three questions are also quite important. Individuals with LD may lack resilience when receiving negative reactions or when they feel they are not making progress in learning.

chapter.title: Activity: Identify ways you can help individuals with LD be proactive
chapter.content:
Activity: Identify ways you can help individuals with LD be proactive

Based on this information, and your own experiences, consider what you can do as a service provider to help individuals with LD learn to be proactive.

Again, please record for yourself at least one thing you can do to support individuals with LD to be more proactive.

After you have finished recording your ideas, click the forward arrow to continue.

chapter.title: Ideas for helping individuals with LD be proactive
chapter.content:
Ideas for helping individuals with LD be proactive

Some ideas for supporting individuals with LD to be proactive include:

  • Provide contextualized instruction, such as using relevant situations from participants’ lives to teach written and oral communication.
  • Connect possible consequences with actions.
  • Encourage individuals to ask questions.
  • Encourage appropriate peer assistance.
  • Help individuals identify persons who can support their goals and plan how to communicate with these persons.

Take a moment to compare your ideas with those listed.

There is a very important part of self-determination and learning that follows being proactive.
